question.body: A greenstick fracture of the femur is an incomplete break in which one side of the bone is broken and the other is bent, similar to what often happens when you try to bend/break a “green stick” Which of the following would explain why this phenomena is more common in children than in adults?

multiple_choice.choice: The bones in children are thinner than in adults
The bones in children are more brittle than in adults
Children are more likely to have osteoporosis than adults
Children have a higher cartilage to calcium ratio than adults

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although the bones of children are thinner, this does not explain why greenstick fractures occur more commonly in them.
Incorrect. The bones of children are generally considered less brittle than in adults because children have more “flexible bones”.
Incorrect. Osteoporosis occurs when bone mass decreases. Children have not developed their bone mass yet.
Correct. Their collagen content provides tensile strength on the side of the bone that is stretched, but the side experiencing compressive forces often breaks.

question.body: Which of the following cells is not properly matched with its function in bone formation?

multiple_choice.choice: Mesenchymal - stem cells differentiate into osteoprogenitor cells.
Osteoblasts - become trapped in the matrix, where they differentiate into osteocytes.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Mesenchymal stem cell do differentiate into osteoprogenitor cells.
Incorrect. Osteoblasts that are trapped on the osteiod matrix do become osteocytes.
Correct. Osteoblasts secrete the matrix, osteocytes are mature bone cells.
Incorrect. Chondroblasts do differentiate into mature chondrocytes
